Entry.Definition: This industry group comprises establishments primarily engaged in the specialty trades needed to finish buildings. The work performed may include new work, additions, alterations, or maintenance and repairs.

Entry.Title: Drywall and insulation contractors
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in drywall, plaster work, and building insulation work. Plaster work includes applying plain or ornamental plaster, and installation of lath to receive plaster. The work performed may include new work, additions, alterations, maintenance, and repairs.

Entry.Title: Drywall and insulation contractors
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in drywall, plaster work, and building insulation work. Plaster work includes applying plain or ornamental plaster, and installation of lath to receive plaster. The work performed may include new work, additions, alterations, maintenance, and repairs.

Entry.Title: Painting and wall covering contractors
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in painting, paperhanging and decorating in buildings and painting heavy (engineering) structures. Paint or paper stripping, including sandblasting when it is an incidental part of surface preparation by paint and wall covering contractors, is included in this industry. The work performed may include new work, additions, alterations, maintenance, and repairs.

Entry.Title: Painting and wall covering contractors
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in painting, paperhanging and decorating in buildings and painting heavy (engineering) structures. The type of work performed can be new work, additions, alterations, maintenance, and repairs.

Entry.Title: Flooring contractors
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in the installation of resilient floor tile, carpeting, linoleum, and hardwood flooring. The work performed may include new work, additions, alterations, maintenance, and repairs.

Entry.Title: Flooring contractors
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in the installation of resilient floor tile, carpeting, linoleum, and hardwood flooring. The work performed may include new work, additions, alterations, maintenance, and repairs.

Entry.Title: Tile and terrazzo contractors
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in setting and installing ceramic tile, stone (interior only), and mosaic and/or mixing marble particles and cement to make terrazzo at the job site. The work performed may include new work, additions, alterations, maintenance, and repairs.

Entry.Title: Tile and terrazzo contractors
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in setting and installing ceramic tile, stone (interior only), and mosaic and/or mixing marble particles and cement to make terrazzo at the job site. The work performed may include new work, additions, alterations, maintenance, and repairs.

Entry.Title: Finish carpentry contractors
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in finish carpentry work. The work performed may include new work, additions, alterations, maintenance, and repairs.

Entry.Title: Finish carpentry contractors
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in finish carpentry work. The work performed may include new work, additions, alterations, maintenance, and repairs.

Entry.Title: Other building finishing contractors
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments, not classified to any other industry, primarily engaged in building finishing trade work. The work performed may include new work, additions, alterations, or maintenance and repairs.

Entry.Title: Other building finishing contractors
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments, not classified to any other Canadian industry, primarily engaged in building finishing trade work. The work performed may include new work, additions, alterations, or maintenance and repairs.

Entry.Title: Other specialty trade contractors
Entry.Definition: This industry group comprises establishments, not classified to any other industry group, primarily engaged in site preparation activities and other specialized trade activities such as crane rental with operator, fence installation, sandblasting building exteriors and steeplejack work. The work performed may include new work, additions, alterations, maintenance, and repairs.

Entry.Title: Site preparation contractors
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in site preparation activities, such as excavating and grading, demolition of buildings and other structures, and septic system installation. Earth moving and land clearing for all types of sites, except mine site overburden removal, is included in this industry. Establishments primarily engaged in construction equipment rental with operator (except cranes) are also included.

Entry.Title: Site preparation contractors
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in site preparation activities, such as excavating and grading, demolition of buildings and other structures, and septic system installation.

Entry.Title: All other specialty trade contractors
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments, not classified to any other industry, primarily engaged in specialized construction trades. The work performed may include new work, additions, alterations, maintenance, and repairs.

Entry.Title: All other specialty trade contractors
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments, not classified to any other industry, primarily engaged in specialized construction trades. The work performed may include new work, additions, alterations, maintenance, and repairs.

Entry.Title: Manufacturing
Entry.Definition:
This sector comprises establishments primarily engaged in the chemical, mechanical or physical transformation of materials or substances into new products. These products may be finished, in the sense that they are ready to be used or consumed, or semi-finished, in the sense of becoming a raw material for an establishment to use in further manufacturing. Related activities, such as the assembly of the component parts of manufactured goods; the blending of materials; and the finishing of manufactured products by dyeing, heat-treating, plating and similar operations are also treated as manufacturing activities. Manufacturing establishments are known by a variety of trade designations, such as plants, factories or mills.
Manufacturing establishments may own the materials which they transform or they may transform materials owned by other establishments. Manufacturing may take place in factories or in workers' homes, using either machinery or hand tools.
Units that completely outsource the transformation process but own the input materials are classified to the manufacturing sector. Units that completely outsource the transformation process but do not own the materials are classified to merchant wholesalers in Sector 41 Wholesale trade. These units are in fact buying the completed goods from the producer with the intention to resell it. These units may design the goods being manufactured, and may have some say in the manufacturing process.
Certain activities involving the transformation of goods are classified in other sectors. Some examples are post-harvest activities of agricultural establishments, such as crop drying; logging; the beneficiating of mineral ores; the production of structures by construction establishments; and various activities conducted by retailers, such as meat cutting and the assembly of products such as bicycles and computers.
Sales branches or offices (but not retail stores) maintained by manufacturing, refining, or mining enterprises apart from their plants or mines for the purpose of marketing their products are included in Sector 41 Wholesale trade as merchant wholesalers.

Entry.Title: Food manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This subsector comprises establishments primarily engaged in producing food for human or animal consumption.

Entry.Title: Animal food manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry group comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing food and feed for animals, including pets.

Entry.Title: Animal food manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing food and feed for animals, including pets.

Entry.Title: Dog and cat food manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing dog and cat food.

Entry.Title: Other animal food manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments, not classified to any other Canadian industry, primarily engaged in manufacturing animal food.

Entry.Title: Grain and oilseed milling
Entry.Definition: This industry group comprises establishments primarily engaged in milling grains and oilseeds; refining and blending fats and oils; and making breakfast cereal products.

Entry.Title: Flour milling and malt manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in grinding grains or vegetables; milling, cleaning and polishing rice; or manufacturing malt. Integrated mills, which grind grain and further process the milling products into such products as prepared flour mixes or doughs, are included.

Entry.Title: Flour milling
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in grinding grains, fruits or vegetables, except rice.

Entry.Title: Rice milling and malt manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in milling rice; cleaning and polishing rice; manufacturing rice flour or meal; or manufacturing malt from barley, rye or other grains.

Entry.Title: Starch and vegetable fat and oil manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in wet-milling corn and vegetables; crushing oilseeds and tree nuts and extracting oils; or processing or blending purchased fats and oils.

Entry.Title: Wet corn milling
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in wet-milling corn and other vegetables.

Entry.Title: Oilseed processing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in crushing oilseeds and tree nuts and extracting oils.

Entry.Title: Fat and oil refining and blending
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing fats and oils by processing crude or partially refined oils, for example deodorizing them; or blending purchased fats and oils.

Entry.Title: Breakfast cereal manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing breakfast cereal foods.

Entry.Title: Breakfast cereal manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing breakfast cereal foods.

Entry.Title: Sugar and confectionery product manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry group comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing sugar and confectionery products.

Entry.Title: Sugar manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing raw sugar, sugar syrup and refined sugar from sugar cane, raw cane sugar or sugar beets.

Entry.Title: Sugar manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing raw sugar, sugar syrup and refined sugar from sugar cane, raw cane sugar or sugar beets.

Entry.Title: Non-chocolate confectionery manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing non-chocolate confectionery.

Entry.Title: Non-chocolate confectionery manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing non-chocolate confectionery.

Entry.Title: Chocolate and chocolate confectionery manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing chocolate and chocolate confectionery from cacao beans or purchased chocolate.

Entry.Title: Chocolate and chocolate confectionery manufacturing from cacao beans
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in shelling, roasting and grinding cacao beans into chocolate cacao products and chocolate confectionery.

Entry.Title: Confectionery manufacturing from purchased chocolate
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing chocolate confectionery from purchased chocolate.

Entry.Title: Fruit and vegetable preserving and specialty food manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry group comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing frozen fruits and vegetables; frozen entres and side dishes of several ingredients, except seafood; and fruits and vegetables preserved by pickling, canning, dehydrating and similar processes.

Entry.Title: Frozen food manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing frozen fruits and vegetables; and frozen dinners and side dishes of several ingredients, except seafood.

Entry.Title: Frozen food manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing frozen fruits and vegetables; and frozen dinners and side dishes of several ingredients, except seafood.

Entry.Title: Fruit and vegetable canning, pickling and drying
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in preserving fruits and vegetables by canning, pickling, brining and dehydrating (including freeze-drying). Canning uses heat sterilization; pickling uses vinegar solutions and brining uses salt solutions. Establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing mixtures of dried ingredients, such as soup mixes and salad dressing mixes, are included provided they dehydrate at least one of the ingredients.

Entry.Title: Fruit and vegetable canning, pickling and drying
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in preserving fruits and vegetables by canning, pickling, brining and dehydrating. Canning uses heat sterilization; pickling uses vinegar solutions and brining uses salt solutions.

Entry.Title: Dairy product manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry group comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing dairy products. Establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing substitute products are included.

Entry.Title: Dairy product (except frozen) manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing dairy products, except frozen. Establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing substitute products are included.

Entry.Title: Fluid milk manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing milk and processed milk products.

Entry.Title: Butter, cheese, and dry and condensed dairy product manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing butter, cheese, and dry and condensed dairy products.

Entry.Title: Ice cream and frozen dessert manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing ice cream and other frozen desserts.

Entry.Title: Ice cream and frozen dessert manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing ice cream and other frozen desserts.

Entry.Title: Meat product manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry group comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing meat products.

Entry.Title: Animal slaughtering and processing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in slaughtering beef cattle, hogs, poultry and other animals; preparing processed meats and meat by-products; or rendering animal fat, bones and meat scraps.

Entry.Title: Rendering and meat processing from carcasses
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in rendering animal fat, bones and meat scraps; or preparing meat and meat by-products from carcasses.

Entry.Title: Poultry slaughtering and processing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in slaughtering poultry and small game or preparing processed poultry and small game meat and meat by-products.

Entry.Title: Beef cattle slaughtering
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in slaughtering beef cattle.

Entry.Title: Hog slaughtering
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in slaughtering hogs.

Entry.Title: Other animal slaughtering
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in slaughtering animals, except beef cattle, hogs, poultry and small game.

Entry.Title: Seafood product preparation and packaging
Entry.Definition: This industry group comprises establishments primarily engaged in canning seafood, including soup; smoking, salting and drying seafood; preparing fresh fish by removing heads, fins, scales, bones and entrails; shucking and packing fresh shellfish; processing marine fats and oils; and freezing seafood. Establishments known as floating factory ships, that are engaged in shipboard processing of seafood, are included.

Entry.Title: Seafood product preparation and packaging
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in canning seafood, including soup; smoking, salting and drying seafood; preparing fresh fish by removing heads, fins, scales, bones and entrails; shucking and packing fresh shellfish; processing marine fats and oils; and freezing seafood. Establishments known as floating factory ships, that are engaged in shipboard processing of seafood, are included.

Entry.Title: Seafood product preparation and packaging
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in canning seafood, including soup; smoking, salting and drying seafood; preparing fresh fish by removing heads, fins, scales, bones and entrails; shucking and packing fresh shellfish; processing marine fats and oils; and freezing seafood.

Entry.Title: Bakeries and tortilla manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry group comprises establishments engaged in manufacturing baked goods from flour, not from prepared doughs. Establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing bakery products from flour, for sale to the general public, intended for consumption off the premises, are also included.

Entry.Title: Bread and bakery product manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing bakery products, except cookies and crackers, from flour, not prepared doughs. Establishments classified in this industry primarily sell to commercial customers or to the general public, for consumption off the premises.

Entry.Title: Bakeries, manufacture of products for retail sale
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing bakery products, for sale to the general public, for consumption off the premises. Establishments in this industry make bakery products from flour, not from prepared doughs.

Entry.Title: Commercial bakeries and frozen bakery product manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing bakery products, other than for sale to the general public. Establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing frozen baked products are included. Establishments in this industry make bakery products from flour, not from prepared doughs.

Entry.Title: Cookie, cracker and pasta manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing cookies and crackers; preparing flour mixes and dough from purchased flour; and manufacturing dry pasta.

Entry.Title: Cookie and cracker manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing cookies, crackers, biscuits and similar products.

Entry.Title: Flour mixes, dough, and pasta manufacturing from purchased flour
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing either dry pasta, prepared flour mixes or dough from purchased flour.

Entry.Title: Tortilla manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing tortillas.

Entry.Title: Tortilla manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing tortillas.

Entry.Title: Other food manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry group comprises establishments, not classified to any other industry group, primarily engaged in manufacturing food.

Entry.Title: Snack food manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in salting, roasting, drying, cooking or canning nuts; processing grains or seeds into snacks; manufacturing peanut butter; or manufacturing potato chips, corn chips, popped popcorn, hard pretzels, pork rinds and similar snacks.

Entry.Title: Roasted nut and peanut butter manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in salting, roasting, drying, cooking or canning nuts; processing grains or seeds into snacks; or manufacturing peanut butter.

Entry.Title: Other snack food manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments, not classified to any other Canadian industry, primarily engaged in manufacturing snack foods.

Entry.Title: Coffee and tea manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in roasting coffee; manufacturing coffee and tea extracts and concentrates, including instant and freeze dried; blending tea; or manufacturing herbal tea. Establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing coffee and tea substitutes are included.

Entry.Title: Coffee and tea manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in roasting coffee; manufacturing coffee and tea extracts and concentrates, including instant and freeze dried; blending tea; or manufacturing herbal tea.

Entry.Title: Flavouring syrup and concentrate manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing soft drink concentrates and syrup, and related products for soda fountain use or for making soft drinks.

Entry.Title: Flavouring syrup and concentrate manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing soft drink concentrates and syrup, and related products for soda fountain use or for making soft drinks.

Entry.Title: Seasoning and dressing manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing dressings and seasonings.

Entry.Title: Seasoning and dressing manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing dressings and seasonings.

Entry.Title: All other food manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments, not classified to any other industry, primarily engaged in manufacturing food. Establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing and packaging for individual resale, perishable prepared foods such as salads, fresh pizza, fresh pasta, and peeled or cut vegetables, are included.

Entry.Title: All other food manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments, not classified to any other Canadian industry, primarily engaged in manufacturing food.

Entry.Title: Beverage and tobacco product manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This subsector comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing beverages and tobacco products.

Entry.Title: Beverage manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry group comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing beverages.

Entry.Title: Soft drink and ice manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing soft drinks, ice or bottled water, including that which is naturally carbonated. Water-bottling establishments in this industry purify the water before bottling it.

Entry.Title: Soft drink and ice manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing soft drinks, ice or bottled water. Water-bottling establishments in this industry purify the water before bottling it.

Entry.Title: Breweries
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in brewing beer, ale, malt liquors and non-alcoholic beer.

Entry.Title: Breweries
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in brewing beer, ale, malt liquors and non-alcoholic beer.

Entry.Title: Wineries
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing wine or brandy, from grapes or other fruit. Establishments primarily engaged in growing grapes and manufacturing wine; manufacturing wine from purchased grapes and other fruit; blending wines; or distilling brandy are included.

Entry.Title: Wineries
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing wine or brandy, from grapes or other fruit.

Entry.Title: Distilleries
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in distilling liquor, except brandy; blending liquor; or blending and mixing liquor and other ingredients.

Entry.Title: Distilleries
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in distilling liquor, except brandy; blending liquor; or blending and mixing liquor and other ingredients.

Entry.Title: Tobacco manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry group comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing tobacco products.

Entry.Title: Tobacco stemming and redrying
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in stemming or redrying tobacco. These establishments perform the final sorting, grading, redrying, treating and packing of tobacco leaves, and they typically age the tobacco.

Entry.Title: Tobacco stemming and redrying
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in stemming or redrying tobacco. These establishments perform the final sorting, grading, redrying, treating and packing of tobacco leaves, and they typically age the tobacco.

Entry.Title: Tobacco product manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing cigarettes and other tobacco products.

Entry.Title: Tobacco product manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing cigarettes and other tobacco products.

Entry.Title: Cannabis product manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry group comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing products made from cannabis plants with a level of tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) greater than 0.3%.

Entry.Title: Cannabis product manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing products made from cannabis plants with a level of tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) greater than 0.3%.

Entry.Title: Cannabis product manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing products made from cannabis plants with a level of tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) greater than 0.3%.

Entry.Title: Textile mills
Entry.Definition: This subsector comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing yarn or textile fabrics, or finishing yarn, textile fabrics or clothing. Establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing both fabrics and textile products, except knitted clothing, are included.

Entry.Title: Fibre, yarn and thread mills
Entry.Definition: This industry group comprises establishments primarily engaged in spinning yarn from fibres; texturing, throwing or twisting man-made fibre filaments or purchased yarns; or manufacturing thread for sewing, crocheting, embroidery, tatting and similar uses.

Entry.Title: Fibre, yarn and thread mills
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in spinning yarn from fibres; texturing, throwing or twisting man-made fibre filaments or purchased yarns; or manufacturing thread for sewing, crocheting, embroidery, tatting and similar uses.

Entry.Title: Fibre, yarn and thread mills
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in spinning yarn from fibres; texturing, throwing or twisting man-made fibre filaments or purchased yarns; or manufacturing thread for sewing, crocheting, embroidery, tatting and similar uses.

Entry.Title: Fabric mills
Entry.Definition: This industry group comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing textile fabrics. Establishments classified in this industry group may finish the fabrics that they manufacture. Establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing both fabrics and textile products, except knitted clothing, are included.

Entry.Title: Broad-woven fabric mills
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in weaving broad fabrics. Establishments classified in this industry may finish the fabrics that they weave. Establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing textile products from broad-woven fabrics made in the same establishment are included.

Entry.Title: Broad-woven fabric mills
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in weaving broad fabrics.

Entry.Title: Narrow fabric mills and Schiffli machine embroidery
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in weaving or braiding narrow fabrics; or manufacturing embroideries with Schiffli machines. Establishments classified in this industry may finish the fabrics that they manufacture. Establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing fabric-covered elastic thread, yarn and cord are included.

Entry.Title: Narrow fabric mills and Schiffli machine embroidery
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in weaving or braiding narrow fabrics; or manufacturing embroideries with Schiffli machines.

Entry.Title: Nonwoven fabric mills
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing nonwoven fabrics, by bonding and/or interlocking fibres. Mechanical, chemical, thermal and solvent methods, and combinations thereof, are used. Establishments classified in this industry may finish the fabrics that they manufacture.

Entry.Title: Nonwoven fabric mills
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing nonwoven fabrics, by bonding and/or interlocking fibres. Mechanical, chemical, thermal and solvent methods, and combinations thereof, are used.

Entry.Title: Knit fabric mills
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in knitting fabrics, on both circular (weft fabric) and flat-bed (warp fabric) machines. Establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing double and single knits, warp knits and interlock knits; manufacturing special construction fabrics by the Malimo, Arachne and similar processes; manufacturing knit lace; and making textile products in knitting mills are included. Establishments classified in this industry may finish the fabrics that they knit.

Entry.Title: Knit fabric mills
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in knitting fabrics, on both circular (weft fabric) and flat-bed (warp fabric) machines.

Entry.Title: Textile and fabric finishing and fabric coating
Entry.Definition: This industry group comprises establishments primarily engaged in preparing and finishing yarn and thread, textile fabrics, textile products (except carpets and rugs), and clothing; and manufacturing coated or laminated fabrics.

Entry.Title: Textile and fabric finishing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in preparing and finishing yarn and thread, textile fabrics, textile products (except carpets and rugs), and clothing, not made in the same establishment. Finishing operations include bleaching; dyeing; printing fabrics (roller, screen, flock, plisse); chemical finishing for water repellency, fire resistance and mildew proofing; and mechanical finishing, such as preshrinking, calendering, napping and stone-washing. Establishments, known as converters, primarily engaged in buying fabric in the grey and having it finished by contractors, are included.

Entry.Title: Textile and fabric finishing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in preparing and finishing yarn and thread, textile fabrics, textile products (except carpets and rugs), and clothing, not made in the same establishment. Finishing operations include bleaching; dyeing; printing fabrics (roller, screen, flock, plisse); chemical finishing for water repellency, fire resistance and mildew proofing; and mechanical finishing, such as preshrinking, calendering, napping and stone-washing.

Entry.Title: Fabric coating
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing coated or laminated fabrics; and in finishing textile fabrics or clothing by coating, laminating, rubberizing, varnishing, waxing or similar processes.

Entry.Title: Fabric coating
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing coated or laminated fabrics; and in finishing textile fabrics or clothing by coating, laminating, rubberizing, varnishing, waxing or similar processes.

Entry.Title: Textile product mills
Entry.Definition: This subsector comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing textile products, except clothing.

Entry.Title: Textile furnishings mills
Entry.Definition: This industry group comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing carpets and rugs, and curtains and linens.

Entry.Title: Carpet and rug mills
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing carpets and rugs, including tufted, woven and needle-punched; or in finishing carpets and rugs.

Entry.Title: Carpet and rug mills
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing carpets and rugs, including tufted, woven and needle-punched; or in finishing carpets and rugs.

Entry.Title: Curtain and linen mills
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing curtains, draperies, linens and other home furnishings, from purchased materials.

Entry.Title: Curtain and linen mills
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing curtains, draperies, linens and other home furnishings, from purchased materials.

Entry.Title: Other textile product mills
Entry.Definition: This industry group comprises establishments, not classified to any other industry group, primarily engaged in manufacturing textile products.

Entry.Title: Textile bag and canvas mills
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing textile bags, such as shipping and other industrial bags; or products from canvas or canvas substitutes, such as tarpaulins and tents.

Entry.Title: Textile bag and canvas mills
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing textile bags, such as shipping and other industrial bags; or products from canvas or canvas substitutes, such as tarpaulins and tents.

Entry.Title: All other textile product mills
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments, not classified to any other industry, primarily engaged in manufacturing textile products. Establishments primarily engaged in garneting textile waste or other textile recycling; or embroidering textile products, including clothing, whether or not on a contract basis, are included.

Entry.Title: All other textile product mills
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments, not classified to any other Canadian industry, primarily engaged in manufacturing textile products.

Entry.Title: Apparel manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This subsector comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing clothing.

Entry.Title: Apparel knitting mills
Entry.Definition: This industry group comprises establishments primarily engaged in knitting clothing from yarn; or manufacturing clothing from knit fabrics made in the same establishment. Establishments classified in this industry group may finish the clothing that they knit.

Entry.Title: Apparel knitting mills
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in knitting clothing. Establishments classified in this industry may finish the clothing that they knit.

Entry.Title: Apparel knitting mills
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in knitting clothing. Establishments classified in this industry may finish the clothing that they knit.

Entry.Title: Cut and sew clothing manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry group comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing clothing from fabric made in other establishments.

Entry.Title: Cut and sew clothing contracting
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing clothing from materials owned by others. These establishments are commonly referred to as contractors. This industry is limited to contract establishments that perform cutting and sewing operations, such as sewing arms to shirt bodies.

Entry.Title: Cut and sew clothing contracting
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing clothing from materials owned by others. These establishments are commonly referred to as contractors. This industry is limited to contract establishments that perform cutting and sewing operations, such as sewing arms to shirt bodies.

Entry.Title: Cut and sew apparel manufacturing (except contractors)
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing clothing from purchased fabric. Clothing jobbers, who perform entrepreneurial functions involved in clothing manufacture, such as buying materials, designing and preparing samples, arranging for clothing to be made from their materials, and marketing the finished apparel, are included.

Entry.Title: Cut and sew apparel manufacturing (except contractors)
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing clothing from purchased fabric. Clothing jobbers, who perform entrepreneurial functions involved in clothing manufacture, such as buying materials, designing and preparing samples, arranging for clothing to be made from their materials, and marketing the finished apparel, are included.

Entry.Title: Clothing accessories and other clothing manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry group comprises establishments, not classified to any other industry group, primarily engaged in manufacturing clothing or clothing accessories.

Entry.Title: Clothing accessories and other clothing manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments, not classified to any other industry, primarily engaged in manufacturing clothing or clothing accessories.

Entry.Title: Clothing accessories and other clothing manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments, not classified to any other Canadian industry, primarily engaged in manufacturing clothing or clothing accessories.

Entry.Title: Leather and allied product manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This subsector comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing leather and allied products.

Entry.Title: Leather and hide tanning and finishing
Entry.Definition: This industry group comprises establishments primarily engaged in tanning, currying, colouring and finishing hides and skins into leather. Leather converters, who buy hides and skins and have them processed into leather by others, on a contract basis, are included. Establishments primarily engaged in dressing and dyeing fur are also included.

Entry.Title: Leather and hide tanning and finishing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in tanning, currying, colouring and finishing hides and skins into leather. Leather converters, who buy hides and skins and have them processed into leather by others, on a contract basis, are included. Establishments primarily engaged in dressing and dyeing fur are also included.

Entry.Title: Leather and hide tanning and finishing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in tanning, currying, colouring and finishing hides and skins into leather.

Entry.Title: Footwear manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry group comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing footwear, of any material.

Entry.Title: Footwear manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing footwear, of any material.

Entry.Title: Footwear manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing footwear, of any material.

Entry.Title: Other leather and allied product manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry group comprises establishments, not classified to any other industry group, primarily engaged in manufacturing leather and allied products. Some important products of this industry are luggage, handbags, purses, and small articles normally carried on the person or in a handbag, such as billfolds, key cases and coin purses of leather or other materials, except precious metal.

Entry.Title: Other leather and allied product manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments, not classified to any other industry, primarily engaged in manufacturing leather and allied products. Some important products of this industry are luggage, handbags, purses, and small articles normally carried on the person or in a handbag, such as billfolds, key cases and coin purses of leather or other materials, except precious metal.

Entry.Title: Other leather and allied product manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments, not classified to any other Canadian industry, primarily engaged in manufacturing leather and allied products. Some important products of this industry are small articles normally carried on the person or in a handbag, such as billfolds, key cases and coin purses of leather or other materials, except precious metal.

Entry.Title: Wood product manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This subsector comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing products from wood. There are three industry groups in this subsector, comprising establishments engaged in sawing logs into lumber and similar products, or preserving these products; making products that improve the natural characteristics of wood, by making veneers, plywood, reconstituted wood panel products or engineered wood assemblies; and making a diverse range of wood products, such as millwork.

Entry.Title: Sawmills and wood preservation
Entry.Definition: This industry group comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing boards, dimension lumber, timber, poles and ties from logs and bolts. These establishments produce lumber that may be rough, or dressed by a planing machine to achieve smoothness and uniformity of size, but is generally not further worked or shaped. Establishments that preserve wood are also included.

Entry.Title: Sawmills and wood preservation
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing boards, dimension lumber, timber, poles and ties from logs and bolts. These establishments produce lumber that may be rough, or dressed by a planing machine to achieve smoothness and uniformity of size, but is generally not further worked or shaped. Establishments that preserve wood are also included.

Entry.Title: Sawmills (except shingle and shake mills)
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing boards, dimension lumber, timber, poles and ties, and siding, from logs and bolts. These establishments produce lumber that may be rough, or dressed by a planing machine to achieve smoothness and uniformity of size, but (except in the case of siding) is generally not further worked or shaped.

Entry.Title: Shingle and shake mills
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in sawing blocks of wood to produce shingles or splitting blocks of wood to produce shakes.

Entry.Title: Wood preservation
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in treating lumber, plywood, poles and similar wood products, produced in other establishments, with preservatives to prevent decay and to protect against fire and insects. Pressure treating is the most common method used.

Entry.Title: Veneer, plywood and engineered wood product manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry group comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing softwood and hardwood veneer and plywood; structural wood members, except lumber; and reconstituted wood panel products. Veneer is produced as a thin sheet of wood of uniform thickness by peeling or slicing logs. Plywood is produced by gluing and compressing together, three or more sheets of veneer, with the grain of alternate sheets usually laid crosswise. Structural wood members are made by laminating, joining and assembling wood components according to specified engineering design criteria. Reconstituted wood panel products are produced by processes involving pressure, adhesives and binders. The laminated products produced in this industry may have layers of materials other than wood.

Entry.Title: Veneer, plywood and engineered wood product manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing softwood and hardwood veneer and plywood; structural wood members, except lumber; and reconstituted wood panel products. Veneer is produced as a thin sheet of wood of uniform thickness by peeling or slicing logs. Plywood is produced by gluing and compressing together, three or more sheets of veneer, with the grain of alternate sheets usually laid crosswise. Structural wood members are made by laminating, joining and assembling wood components according to specified engineering design criteria. Reconstituted wood panel products are produced by processes involving pressure, adhesives and binders. The laminated products produced in this industry may have layers of materials other than wood.

Entry.Title: Hardwood veneer and plywood mills
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing hardwood veneer and plywood.

Entry.Title: Softwood veneer and plywood mills
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing softwood veneer and plywood.

Entry.Title: Structural wood product manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing structural wood members, other than solid dimension lumber and timber.

Entry.Title: Particle board and fibreboard mills
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing particle board and fibreboard. Particle board is made from wood particles, which are often the residue from other wood processing operations, combined under heat and pressure with a water resistant binder. Fibreboard is made from wood fibres, bonded together completely or partially by the lignin in the wood.

Entry.Title: Waferboard mills
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing waferboard and oriented strandboard (OSB). These products are made from wafers or strands of wood such as aspen, poplar or southern yellow pine, combined with a waterproof binder, and bonded together by heat and pressure.

Entry.Title: Other wood product manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry group comprises establishments, not classified to any other industry group, primarily engaged in manufacturing wood products.

Entry.Title: Millwork
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in millwork. These establishments generally use woodworking machinery, such as jointers, planers, lathes and routers, to shape wood. Establishments primarily engaged in seasoning and planing purchased lumber are included. Wood millwork products may be covered with another material, such as plastic.

Entry.Title: Wood window and door manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing wood doors and frames, and wood window units and frames.

Entry.Title: Other millwork
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments, not classified to any other Canadian industry, primarily engaged in millwork. These establishments generally use woodworking machinery, such as jointers, planers, lathes and routers, to shape wood.

Entry.Title: Wood container and pallet manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing wood containers, container parts (shook) ready for assembly, cooper's products and parts, and pallets.

Entry.Title: Wood container and pallet manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing wood containers, container parts (shook) ready for assembly, cooper's products and parts, and pallets.

Entry.Title: All other wood product manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments, not classified to any other industry, primarily engaged in manufacturing wood products.

Entry.Title: Manufactured (mobile) home manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing mobile homes and non-residential mobile buildings. These units are portable structures built on a chassis equipped with wheels, but not designed for multiple or continuous movement, and are designed to be connected to sewage and water utilities.

Entry.Title: Prefabricated wood building manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing prefabricated or pre-cut wood buildings, sections and panels.

Entry.Title: All other miscellaneous wood product manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments, not classified to any other Canadian industry, primarily engaged in manufacturing wood products.

Entry.Title: Paper manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This subsector comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing pulp, paper and paper products. The manufacture of pulp involves separating the cellulose fibres from other impurities in wood, used paper or other fibre sources. The manufacture of paper involves matting these fibres into a sheet. Converted paper products are produced from paper and other materials by various cutting and shaping techniques.

Entry.Title: Pulp, paper and paperboard mills
Entry.Definition: This industry group comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing pulp, paper or paperboard. Establishments that manufacture pulp, paper or paperboard, either alone or in combination with paper converting, are included.

Entry.Title: Pulp mills
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing pulp from any material, by any process. These establishments sell or transfer the pulp to separate paper-making establishments; they do not make it into paper themselves. Establishments that process waste paper into pulp (de-inking plants) are included.

Entry.Title: Mechanical pulp mills
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing pulp from any material, using mechanical or semi-chemical methods. Some important products of this Canadian industry are mechanical pulp (sometimes called groundwood pulp), thermo-mechanical pulp (TMP) and semi-chemical pulp.

Entry.Title: Chemical pulp mills
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing pulp from any material, using chemical methods. Kraft pulp is chemical pulp obtained from the sulphate or soda processes.

Entry.Title: Paper mills
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing paper, other than paperboard. Establishments that manufacture paper in combination with pulp manufacture or paper converting, are included.

Entry.Title: Paper (except newsprint) mills
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing paper, other than newsprint and paperboard.

Entry.Title: Newsprint mills
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing newsprint.

Entry.Title: Paperboard mills
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing paperboard. Establishments that manufacture paperboard in combination with pulp manufacture or paperboard converting, are included.

Entry.Title: Paperboard mills
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing paperboard.

Entry.Title: Converted paper product manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry group comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing paper products from purchased paper and paperboard.

Entry.Title: Paperboard container manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing paperboard containers, such as setup paperboard boxes, corrugated boxes, fibre boxes, cans and drums, and sanitary food containers, from purchased paperboard. These establishments use corrugating and cutting machinery to form paperboard into containers.

Entry.Title: Corrugated and solid fibre box manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing corrugated and solid fibre boxes and related products, such as corrugated sheets, from purchased paperboard.

Entry.Title: Folding paperboard box manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing folding paperboard boxes, from purchased paperboard.

Entry.Title: Other paperboard container manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments, not classified to any other Canadian industry, primarily engaged in manufacturing paperboard containers, such as setup paperboard boxes, fibre cans and drums, and sanitary food containers, from purchased paperboard.

Entry.Title: Paper bag and coated and treated paper manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing paper bags, and coated and treated paper and paperboard products, from purchased paper and other flexible film materials. The products produced in this industry may be made from a single layer; or from several layers laminated together. The laminated products may consist entirely of materials other than paper, such as plastic film and aluminum foil.

Entry.Title: Paper bag and coated and treated paper manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing paper bags, and coated and treated paper and paperboard products, from purchased paper and other flexible film materials.

Entry.Title: Stationery product manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing paper stationery products, used for writing, filing and similar applications.

Entry.Title: Stationery product manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing paper stationery products, used for writing, filing and similar applications.

Entry.Title: Other converted paper product manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments, not classified to any other industry, primarily engaged in manufacturing paper products from purchased paper and paperboard.

Entry.Title: Sanitary paper product manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing converted paper sanitary products from purchased paper.

Entry.Title: All other converted paper product manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments, not classified to any other Canadian industry, primarily engaged in manufacturing converted paper products, from purchased paper.

Entry.Title: Printing and related support activities
Entry.Definition: This subsector comprises establishments primarily engaged in printing and providing related support activities.

Entry.Title: Printing and related support activities
Entry.Definition: This industry group comprises establishments primarily engaged in printing and providing related support activities.

Entry.Title: Printing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in printing.

Entry.Title: Commercial screen printing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in commercial printing using silk-screen printing equipment. Establishments in this Canadian industry typically have a pre-press capability, for example, to cut stencils. Typically, these establishments print on clothing; or produce paper documents of a graphical nature, such as pictures and large-format sign-type lettering.

Entry.Title: Quick printing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in commercial printing using small offset printers and/or non-impact printers. Establishments in this Canadian industry typically have a pre-press capability.

Entry.Title: Digital printing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in digital printing. These establishments use computer-controlled non-impact (electrostatic, ink jet, spray jet) printing equipment. The image to be printed is input to the printer as a computer file (not simply scanned in and digitized by the printer itself). Establishments in this Canadian industry typically have extensive pre-press operations, including specialized scanners and colour-separation equipment. Typically, these establishments print documents of a high-resolution, graphical nature.

Entry.Title: Manifold business forms printing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in printing manifold business forms.

Entry.Title: Other printing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments, not classified to any other Canadian industry, primarily engaged in printing.

Entry.Title: Support activities for printing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in providing support services to commercial printers, such as pre-press and bindery work.

Entry.Title: Support activities for printing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in providing support services to commercial printers, such as pre-press and bindery work.

Entry.Title: Petroleum and coal product manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This subsector comprises establishments primarily engaged in transforming crude petroleum and coal into intermediate and end products. The dominant process is petroleum refining, which separates crude petroleum into components or fractions through such techniques as cracking and distillation.

Entry.Title: Petroleum and coal product manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry group comprises establishments primarily engaged in transforming crude petroleum and coal into intermediate and end products. The dominant process is petroleum refining, which separates crude petroleum into components or fractions through such techniques as cracking and distillation.

Entry.Title: Petroleum refineries
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in refining crude petroleum. Petroleum refining involves the transformation of crude oil by such processes as cracking and distillation.

Entry.Title: Petroleum refineries
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in refining crude petroleum. Petroleum refining involves the transformation of crude oil by such processes as cracking and distillation.

Entry.Title: Asphalt paving, roofing and saturated materials manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing asphalt paving materials; manufacturing roofing rolls, sheets and shingles, by saturating mats and felts with purchased asphalt or bituminous materials; and manufacturing roofing cements and coatings.

Entry.Title: Asphalt paving mixture and block manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing asphalt paving mixtures and blocks, from purchased asphalt, bituminous materials or coal tar.

Entry.Title: Asphalt shingle and coating material manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing roofing rolls, sheets and shingles, by saturating mats and felts with purchased asphalt or bituminous materials; and manufacturing roofing cements and coatings.

Entry.Title: Other petroleum and coal product manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments, not classified to any other industry, primarily engaged in manufacturing petroleum and coal products. Establishments primarily engaged in re-refining used products are included.

Entry.Title: Other petroleum and coal product manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments, not classified to any other Canadian industry, primarily engaged in manufacturing petroleum and coal products.

Entry.Title: Chemical manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This subsector comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing chemicals and chemical preparations, from organic and inorganic raw materials.

Entry.Title: Basic chemical manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry group comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing chemicals, using basic processes such as thermal cracking and distillation. Chemicals produced in this industry group are usually separate chemical elements or separate chemically-defined compounds.

Entry.Title: Petrochemical manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in converting feedstocks derived from petroleum, or from petroleum and natural gas liquids, into petrochemicals. Some important processes used in petrochemical manufacturing include steam cracking and steam reforming. For the purpose of defining this industry, petrochemicals consist of acyclic (aliphatic) hydrocarbons and cyclic aromatic hydrocarbons.

Entry.Title: Petrochemical manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in converting feedstocks derived from petroleum, or from petroleum and natural gas liquids, into petrochemicals. Some important processes used in petrochemical manufacturing include steam cracking and steam reforming. For the purpose of defining this industry, petrochemicals consist of acyclic (aliphatic) hydrocarbons and cyclic aromatic hydrocarbons.

Entry.Title: Industrial gas manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing industrial organic and inorganic gases in compressed, liquid and solid forms.

Entry.Title: Industrial gas manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing industrial organic and inorganic gases in compressed, liquid and solid forms.

Entry.Title: Synthetic dye and pigment manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing synthetic organic and inorganic dyes, pigments, lakes and toners.

Entry.Title: Synthetic dye and pigment manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing synthetic organic and inorganic dyes, pigments, lakes and toners.

Entry.Title: Other basic inorganic chemical manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments, not classified to any other industry, primarily engaged in manufacturing basic inorganic chemicals.

Entry.Title: Alkali and chlorine manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing alkalies and chlorine, often using an electrolysis process.

Entry.Title: All other basic inorganic chemical manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments, not classified to any other Canadian industry, primarily engaged in manufacturing inorganic chemicals.

Entry.Title: Other basic organic chemical manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments, not classified to any other industry, primarily engaged in manufacturing basic organic chemicals. Establishments primarily engaged in coal tar distillation, the distillation of wood products or the manufacture of ethanol (ethyl alcohol) for non-beverage use are included. The main products of this class are vinyl chloride, methanol, alicyclic hydrocarbon, ethylene glycol, fatty acids and esters.

Entry.Title: Other basic organic chemical manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments, not classified to any other Canadian industry, primarily engaged in manufacturing basic organic chemicals.

Entry.Title: Resin, synthetic rubber, and artificial and synthetic fibres and filaments manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry group comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing polymers such as resins, synthetic rubber, and textile fibres and filaments. Polymerization of monomers into polymers, for example of styrene into polystyrene, is the basic process.

Entry.Title: Resin and synthetic rubber manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing synthetic resins, plastics materials and synthetic rubber from basic organic chemicals.

Entry.Title: Resin and synthetic rubber manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing synthetic resins, plastics materials and synthetic rubber from basic organic chemicals.

Entry.Title: Artificial and synthetic fibres and filaments manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing artificial and synthetic fibres and filaments in the form of monofilament, filament yarn, staple or tow. Artificial fibres are made from organic polymers derived from natural raw materials, mainly cellulose. Synthetic fibres are generally derived from petrochemicals. Establishments that both manufacture and texture fibres are included.

Entry.Title: Artificial and synthetic fibres and filaments manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing artificial and synthetic fibres and filaments in the form of monofilament, filament yarn, staple or tow. Artificial fibres are made from organic polymers derived from natural raw materials, mainly cellulose. Synthetic fibres are generally derived from petrochemicals.

Entry.Title: Pesticide, fertilizer and other agricultural chemical manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry group comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing agricultural chemicals, including nitrogenous and phosphoric fertilizer materials; mixed fertilizers; and agricultural and household pest control chemicals.

Entry.Title: Fertilizer manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing nitrogenous or phosphoric fertilizer materials and mixing these ingredients into fertilizers; and in purchasing ingredients and mixing them into fertilizers. Establishments engaged in the manufacture of phosphoric acid, urea, ammonia and nitric acid, whether or not for use as a fertilizer material, are included.

Entry.Title: Chemical fertilizer (except potash) manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing nitrogenous and phosphoric fertilizer materials and mixing these ingredients with other ingredients into fertilizers.

Entry.Title: Mixed fertilizer manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in mixing ingredients produced elsewhere into fertilizers.

Entry.Title: Pesticide and other agricultural chemical manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing agricultural chemicals, except fertilizers. Establishments engaged in manufacturing household pest control products are included.

Entry.Title: Pesticide and other agricultural chemical manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing agricultural chemicals, except fertilizers.

Entry.Title: Pharmaceutical and medicine manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry group comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing drugs, medicines and related products for human or animal use. Establishments in this industry may undertake one or more of several processes, including basic processes, such as chemical synthesis, fermentation, distillation and solvent extraction; grading, grinding and milling; and packaging in forms suitable for internal and external use, such as tablets, vials, ampoules and ointments.

Entry.Title: Pharmaceutical and medicine manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing drugs, medicines and related products for human or animal use. Establishments in this industry may undertake one or more of several processes, including basic processes, such as chemical synthesis, fermentation, distillation and solvent extraction; grading, grinding and milling; and packaging in forms suitable for internal and external use, such as tablets, vials, ampoules and ointments.

Entry.Title: Pharmaceutical and medicine manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing drugs, medicines and related products for human or animal use.

Entry.Title: Paint, coating and adhesive manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry group comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing paints, coatings and adhesives.

Entry.Title: Paint and coating manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in mixing pigments, solvents and binders into paints, stains and other coatings; and manufacturing related products.

Entry.Title: Paint and coating manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in mixing pigments, solvents and binders into paints, stains and other coatings; and manufacturing related products.

Entry.Title: Adhesive manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing glue, adhesives and related products.

Entry.Title: Adhesive manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing glue, adhesives and related products.

Entry.Title: Soap, cleaning compound and toilet preparation manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry group comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing soap and other cleaning compounds and toilet preparations.

Entry.Title: Soap and cleaning compound manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing soap and other cleaning compounds.

Entry.Title: Soap and cleaning compound manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing soap and other cleaning compounds.

Entry.Title: Toilet preparation manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in preparing, blending and compounding toilet preparations.

Entry.Title: Toilet preparation manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in preparing, blending and compounding toilet preparations.

Entry.Title: Other chemical product manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry group comprises establishments, not classified to any other industry group, primarily engaged in manufacturing chemical products.

Entry.Title: Printing ink manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing printing inks and ink jet inks, whether black or coloured. Establishments engaged in the manufacture of ink jet cartridges are included.

Entry.Title: Printing ink manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing printing inks and ink jet inks, whether black or coloured.

Entry.Title: Explosives manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing explosive preparations, detonators for explosives, and explosive devices, except ammunition.

Entry.Title: Explosives manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing explosive preparations, detonators for explosives, and explosive devices, except ammunition.

Entry.Title: All other chemical product manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments, not classified to any other industry, primarily engaged in manufacturing chemical products.

Entry.Title: Custom compounding of purchased resins
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in the custom mixing and blending of purchased plastics resins; and compounding plastics resins from recycled plastics products.

Entry.Title: All other miscellaneous chemical product manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments, not classified to any other Canadian industry, primarily engaged in manufacturing chemical products.

Entry.Title: Plastics and rubber products manufacturing
Entry.Definition:
This subsector comprises establishments primarily engaged in making goods by processing raw rubber and plastics materials. Rubber and plastics-based activities are combined in the same subsector because the technical properties of these polymers are related.
Generally, establishments classified in this subsector manufacture products made of just one material, rubber or plastics, with the major exception of tire manufacturing.

Entry.Title: Plastic product manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry group comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing intermediate or final products from plastics resins, using such processes as compression moulding, extrusion moulding, injection moulding, blow moulding and casting. The production process in most of these industries is such that a wide variety of products can be produced. The plastics resins used by these establishments may be new or recycled.

Entry.Title: Plastic packaging materials and unlaminated film and sheet manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in converting plastic resins into unsupported plastic films, sheets and bags and those that form, coat or laminate unsupported plastic films and sheets into unsupported plastic bags.

Entry.Title: Plastic bag and pouch manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in converting plastics resins into unsupported plastic bags and those that only form, coat or laminate plastic or cellulose films and sheets into unsupported plastic bags.

Entry.Title: Plastic film and sheet manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in converting plastics resins into unsupported plastic film and sheet.

Entry.Title: Plastic pipe, pipe fitting, and unlaminated profile shape manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing unsupported plastic profile shapes or plastic pipes and pipe fittings.

Entry.Title: Unlaminated plastic profile shape manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in converting plastics resins into unsupported plastic profile shapes, except films, sheets and bags.

Entry.Title: Plastic pipe and pipe fitting manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in converting plastics resins into plastic pipes and pipe fittings.

Entry.Title: Laminated plastic plate, sheet (except packaging), and shape manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in laminating plastic profile shapes, such as plates, sheets and rods. The lamination process generally involves bonding or impregnating profiles with plastics resins and compressing them under heat.

Entry.Title: Laminated plastic plate, sheet (except packaging), and shape manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in laminating plastic profile shapes, such as plates, sheets and rods. The lamination process generally involves bonding or impregnating profiles with plastics resins and compressing them under heat.

Entry.Title: Polystyrene foam product manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in converting polystyrene resins into foam products.

Entry.Title: Polystyrene foam product manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This Canadian industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in converting polystyrene resins into foam products.

Entry.Title: Urethane and other foam product (except polystyrene) manufacturing
Entry.Definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in converting plastics resins, other than polystyrene, into foam products.

Entry.Title: Urethane and other foam product (except polystyrene) manufacturing
